newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire rebels agree to airlift home for refugees.
newsitem.headline: Zaire rebels agree to airlift home for refugees.

text.p: Zairean rebels agreed on Saturday to a repatriation airlift for up to 100,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees trapped deep inside Zaire, European Union special envoy Aldo Aiello told reporters.
"I've got a message just a few minutes ago from Mr (Laurent) Kabila that the Kisangani airport will be open and will be made available for the repatriation of refugees," he said in Kasangani.

The U.N. Security Council, the European Union, Belgium, France and aid groups have called on Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (AFDL) rebels to allow access to Rwandan refugees dying of malnutrition and disease.

Filippo Grandi of the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR said he hoped the airlift with chartered aircraft could start in a few days. He said it might last two to three months and would cost less than his earlier estimate of $50 million.
Kabila's senior official dealing with the United Nations, Emmanuel Kamanze, flew to Kisangani with Aiello from rebel headquarters in Goma in eastern Zaire to confirm the airlift agreement.
Zairean rebels had angrily rejected accusations by the international community that they were hindering aid groups trying to help refugees in the east of the country.
Rebel representatives in South Africa for peace talks with the Zairean authorities said earlier they had done their utmost to help relief organisations.

"We have compromised...because we believe that those refugees are, like our population, victims of a dictatorial regime which has been using them as human shields," rebel spokesman Bizima Karaha told reporters.

Kabila's forces, who have seized a third of the Central African Country, had compromised except where this might harm their own security, said a visibly angry Karaha outside South African government headquarters in Pretoria.
